topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Casey Winters, highlights companies he’s worked with, and previews key topics like trade-offs, growth strategy, and leveling up PM skills.

topics.title: Coda content loops and sharing best practices
topics.summary: Casey explains why he loves Coda: strong content loops where templates are shared publicly, copied, and adapted—embedding scaling best practices into product-led growth.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Coda, Mixpanel, and later Whimsical, including offers and brief positioning on product analytics and collaborative product work.

topics.title: Casey’s career arc through product and growth
topics.summary: Casey walks through his path from marketing analytics to growth roles at GrubHub, leading growth at Pinterest, advising via Greylock, and becoming CPO at Eventbrite.

topics.title: Communicating trade-offs and escalating issues upward
topics.summary: Casey explains why leaders often under-communicate problems upward, how that creates unfair evaluation and misalignment, and how to frame updates as a coherent story (not “chapter six”).

topics.title: Coaching PMs for exec meetings and pre-alignment
topics.summary: He describes role-playing exec Q&A, tailoring to each executive’s concerns, and using pre-meetings to de-risk big reviews so there are fewer surprises in the room.

topics.title: How much preparation matters for high-leverage meetings
topics.summary: Casey shares that prep time varies by person, but the standard is being ready for the full universe of likely questions—because key decisions hinge on these forums.

topics.title: Keeping products simple while adding power
topics.summary: Casey discusses the “simple → complex → users leave” cycle and why Eventbrite aims for perceived simplicity: advanced features discoverable when needed but effectively hidden otherwise.

topics.title: Eventbrite example: simple defaults, advanced marketing controls
topics.summary: He gives a concrete win: automated Facebook ads with a simple default experience for non-marketers plus an on-ramp for sophisticated creators who want more control.

topics.title: Justifying non-sexy investments like performance and velocity
topics.summary: Casey explains why hard-to-measure work is chronically underfunded and offers tactics: custom metrics, small tests, principles/OKRs, and building cross-functional buy-in first.

topics.title: Protecting gains: product-market fit decays over time
topics.summary: He argues that at scale you must prevent erosion of what you’ve built; expectations and competition rise, so neglecting quality/UX/latency can push you out of PMF later.

topics.title: Ops teams as a temporary hack, not a permanent function
topics.summary: Casey’s take: ops roles can signal inefficiency if they become long-term manual process owners; the best ops teams automate and eliminate the need for themselves.

topics.title: What a CPO does and how to become one
topics.summary: Casey defines the CPO job as delivering customer value that translates to business value, improving strategy and execution processes, removing bottlenecks, and developing/hiring talent; he advises optimizing for company-first and avoiding overspecialization.

topics.title: Spectrum of PMs: innovators vs executors
topics.summary: He outlines two extremes—idea generators and execution-focused PMs—why leaders often hire executors, and how teams must develop strategy skills to move people toward the middle.

topics.title: Strategy as the key filter for senior PM growth
topics.summary: Casey argues early PM success is shipping value, but advancement requires independently writing and driving strategy; lacking this caps careers at senior/GPM levels.

topics.title: Transition to growth: channels getting harder
topics.summary: Lenny tees up the next discussion: paid growth is pricier post-Apple changes, SEO is crowded, sales is expensive—asking Casey what new tactics or channels he’s seeing.
